item.title: Rediscovering Markov Chains[Draft]
item.dc:creator: girishvarma
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes when i have read up some topic, it often happens that half way, i understand that "i dont understand it". At this point i try to build up the theory by myself with minimal help from the book(i think its called Socratic Questioning). At one such situation i did take the pain of writing it up and thats whats this post is about. This post will be evolving, ie hopefully some time in the future i will feel like improving on the post. You might find it badly written or formatted for now.

1. What is it that we want to model?

Suppose we have a system, with $latex {S}&fg=000000$ as the set of all possible states(say finite or countably infinite). There is some uncertainity involed in evolution of the system in time. Suppose the time is discrete(that is integer valued and not real valued). Suppose the evolution happens like this : From the current state $latex {i}&fg=000000$, it always goes to another state $latex {j\in S}&fg=000000$ with probability $latex {p_{ji}}&fg=000000$(so surely $latex {\sum_{j}p_{ji}=1}&fg=000000$). And this happens independent of how the system came to $latex {i}&fg=000000$. Such a system can be represeted by a graph with probabilities associated with edges. And it can be thought of as probabilities flowing through the graph.

See Feller chapter 15 for examples. An interesting example : There is a famous paper on Shuffling cards which can also be modelled according to a Markov Chain.

Suppose we want to invent the mathematics for analysing such a system. With this mathematics we want to answer questions like

  • What is the probability that system is at state $latex {j}&fg=000000$ given that it started at $latex {i}&fg=000000$?
  • What is the probability that if system starts at $latex {i}&fg=000000$, it will visit $latex {j}&fg=000000$ at all?
  • What is the probability that if system starts at $latex {i}&fg=000000$, it will visit $latex {j}&fg=000000$ infinitely often?
  • After sometime does the system attain a equilibrium(ie the probabilty distribution on $latex {S}&fg=000000$ will not change with respect to time)?
  • What is the time average of my visits to different states?
To start of with we have the basic probability rules. But it will be found that some clever use of matrices and results from linear algebra will help better in answering the questions.

2. A Model

Here is a nice mathematical model based on basic probability theory:

A Markov Chain is a sequence of random variables $latex {(X_{t})_{t\geq0}}&fg=000000$, where each $latex {X_{t}}&fg=000000$ is distributed according to the distribution $latex {\pi^{t}}&fg=000000$ in $latex {S}&fg=000000$ such that

$latex {Pr[X_{t}=x_{t}|X_{t-1}=x_{t-1},\ \cdots,\ X_{0}=x_{0}]=Pr[X_{t}=x_{t}|X_{t-1}=x_{t-1}]}&fg=000000$ denote this probability by $latex {p_{x_{t}x_{t-1}}}&fg=000000$.

Exercise :$latex {Pr[X_{t}=x_{t},\ X_{t-1}=x_{t-1},\ \cdots,\ X_{0}=x_{0}]=p_{x_{t}x_{t-1}}p_{x_{t-1}x_{t-2}}\cdots p_{x_{1}x_{0}}\pi_{x_{0}}^{0}}&fg=000000$

Now let see the the utility of matrices here. Suppose we denote the matrix $latex {P=(p_{ij})}&fg=000000$, the columns sum upto 1. Lets assume that $latex {S=[n]=\left\{ 1,\ \cdots n\right\} }&fg=000000$ and consider the distributions $latex {\pi^{t}}&fg=000000$ as column vectors.

Verify : $latex {\pi^{1}=P\pi^{0}}&fg=000000$ (or more generally $latex {\pi^{t}=P\pi^{t-1}}&fg=000000$, which implies $latex {\pi^{t}=P^{t}\pi^{0}}&fg=000000$)

Exercise : Show that if i denote $latex {Pr[X_{t}=i|X_{0}=j]=p_{ij}^{(t)}}&fg=000000$, then $latex {p_{ij}^{(t)}}&fg=000000$ is actually the $latex {ij}&fg=000000$th entry of $latex {P^{t}}&fg=000000$.

Exercise : If i define $latex {p_{ij}^{(0)}=\delta_{ij}}&fg=000000$(ie $latex {=1}&fg=000000$ if $latex {i=j}&fg=000000$ and $latex {0}&fg=000000$ otherwise) $latex { }&fg=000000$, then $latex {p_{ij}^{(n+1)}=\sum_{k}p_{ik}^{(n)}p_{kj}}&fg=000000$

Exercise : Also by the graph model $latex {p_{ij}^{(t)}=\sum_{\mbox{all paths from i to j of length t}}Pr[path]}&fg=000000$ (see the prev exercise if you dont understand what is meant by the probability of a path). Reinterpret previous exercise by this method.

Big Idea here is : matrix multiplication can be thought of in terms of a graphs and flows.

So we saw three ways of thinking about Markov Chains, in terms of sequence of random variables, matrix multiplication and walks on graphs. There is yet another way in terms of trees with degree n, or subintervals of $latex {(0,1]}&fg=000000$. Consider the $latex {(0,1]}&fg=000000$ interval, divide it into n intervals of size $latex {\pi_{1}^{0}\cdots\pi_{n}^{0}}&fg=000000$. Now further subdivide each of the intervals $latex {\pi_{i}^{0}}&fg=000000$ into $latex {n}&fg=000000$ subintervals of $latex {p_{ji}\pi_{i}^{0}}&fg=000000$ for each $latex {j}&fg=000000$ (if you are a big time mathematician who knows measure theory, then you would say this is how you construct a sigma algebra for a Markov Chain) and continue ad infinitum. The advantage of this is that any event that you want to talk of about a Markov Chain is the union of disjoint intervals constructed above.

Exercise : What is the probability that the system start in $latex {i}&fg=000000$ and reaches $latex {j}&fg=000000$ in $latex {t}&fg=000000$ steps, in terms of the intervals constructed above, (ie it is the union of disjoint intervals at some $latex {t}&fg=000000$th step)?

item.title: Graph Entropy
item.dc:creator: girishvarma
item.content:encoded:
Lecture Notes from Jaikumar Radhakrishnan's Information Theory Course, scribed by me Suppose Alice receives letters $latex {X_{1}X_{2}X_{3}\cdots}&fg=000000$ from a finite alphabet(say $latex [n] = \{1,\cdots,n\}&fg=000000$), each letter according to a probability distribution $latex {P}&fg=000000$. She wants to communicate this to Bob. We know that for doing source coding she needs $latex {H(P)}&fg=000000$ bits per instance(called the rate). But now Bob doesn't need to distinguish between some pairs of letters in $latex {[n]}&fg=000000$. For each pair of letters in $latex {[n]}&fg=000000$, they are either distinguishable or indistinguishable to him(ie its a symmetric relation). So a natural way to represent this distinguishability relation is an undirected graph $latex {G}&fg=000000$ on $latex {[n]}&fg=000000$(ie $latex {(i,j)}&fg=000000$ edge exists iff $latex {i}&fg=000000$ and $latex {j}&fg=000000$ needs to be distinguished). Example 1: Consider the alphabet $latex {[4]}&fg=000000$, suppose Bob is happy even if he gets a $latex {3}&fg=000000$ instead of $latex {1}&fg=000000$ and $latex {1}&fg=000000$ instead of $latex {3}&fg=000000$ and $latex {4}&fg=000000$ instead of $latex {2}&fg=000000$ and $latex {2}&fg=000000$ instead of $latex {4}&fg=000000$ , then he doesn't need to distinguish between $latex {(1,3),(2,4)}&fg=000000$. The graph corresponding to this situation is a cycle with edge set $latex {\{(1,2),(2,3),(3,4),(4,1)\}}&fg=000000$. Example 2: The normal model in which all alphabets are distinguishable is given by a complete graph. Furthermore if we consider sequences $latex {[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$, not all pairs of sequences are distinguishable to Bob. So again we can construct a graph $latex {G^{k}}&fg=000000$ with vertex set $latex {[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$, such that $latex {(\overline{v},\overline{u})}&fg=000000$ is an edge iff $latex {\exists i,\ (\overline{v}_{i},\overline{u}_{i})\in G}&fg=000000$. $latex {\overline{v},\overline{u}}&fg=000000$ is said to be indistinguishable if there is no edge between them in $latex {G^{k}}&fg=000000$. Now we want to model Bob and also find the best rate at which Alice can communicate to him. Example 3: Consider the alphabet $latex {[5]}&fg=000000$ and let the graph be a pentagon with $latex {1}&fg=000000$ at the top numbered clockwise. So Bob doesn't need to distinguish between $latex {1}&fg=000000$ and $latex {3}&fg=000000$ or $latex {1}&fg=000000$ and $latex {4}&fg=000000$. The sequences $latex {\left\{ 125,343,125\right\} }&fg=000000$ forms a set of pairwise indistinguishable sequences. Note that $latex {\left\{ \left\{ 1,3\right\} ,\left\{ 2,4\right\} ,\left\{ 5\right\} \right\} }&fg=000000$ forms a collection of independent sets of $latex {G}&fg=000000$. Such sets of sequences can be built by making sequences of sets from the collection(say $latex {A_{1}\cdots A_{k}}&fg=000000$). Now consider the set of sequences $latex {\left\{ a_{1}\cdots a_{k}:\forall i,a_{i}\in A_{i}\right\} }&fg=000000$.

1. Modelling Bob

Since Bob cannot distinguish between some sequences anyway. He can only say that Alice received some sequence from some particular set of pairwise indistinguishable sequences. Notice that set of pairwise indistinguishable sequences is nothing but an independent set of $latex {G^{k}}&fg=000000$. So if Alice gets a sequence $latex {\overline{x}\in[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$, Bob just needs to be informed that it is a sequence from an independent set $latex {S}&fg=000000$ of $latex {G^{k}}&fg=000000$. But again independent sets in $latex {G^{k}}&fg=000000$ can be expressed as sequences of independent sets of $latex {G}&fg=000000$ as follows. Let $latex {S\subset[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$ be an independent set which has the sequences $latex {\overline{v}^{1}=v_{11}v_{12}\ \cdots\ v_{1k}}&fg=000000$ $latex {\overline{v}^{2}=v_{21}v_{22}\ \cdots\ v_{2k}}&fg=000000$ $latex {\ \vdots\ }&fg=000000$ $latex {\overline{v}^{t}=v_{t1}v_{t2}\ \cdots\ v_{tk}}&fg=000000$ Since $latex {\overline{v}^{i}}&fg=000000$'s in $latex {S}&fg=000000$ doesn't have any edge in $latex {G^{k}}&fg=000000$, $latex {\forall j\in[k],\ S_{j}=\left\{ v_{1j},\ v_{2j},\cdots v_{tj}\right\} }&fg=000000$ forms an independent set. So for each set $latex {S}&fg=000000$ we get a mapping with a sequence of independent sets $latex {S_{1}S_{2}\cdots S_{k}}&fg=000000$. Conversely for each sequence of independent sets $latex {S_{1}S_{2}\cdots S_{k}}&fg=000000$, we can come up with an independent set for $latex {G^{k}}&fg=000000$, given by $latex {S=\left\{ a_{1}\cdots a_{k}:\forall i,a_{i}\in S_{i}\right\} }&fg=000000$. Goal:
  1. To associate each $latex {\overline{x}\in[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$ with a sequence $latex {\overline{y}\in\mathcal{A}^{k}}&fg=000000$(where $latex {\mathcal{A}}&fg=000000$ is the collection of independent sets of $latex {G}&fg=000000$) such that, $latex {\overline{x}\in}&fg=000000$ independent set represented by $latex {\overline{y}}&fg=000000$.
  2. If the number of $latex {\overline{y}}&fg=000000$'s required is $latex {N}&fg=000000$, minimize $latex {\lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}\frac{log_{2}N}{k}}&fg=000000$ which is the rate.
  3. We can relax 1. to allow errors, ie we will assign $latex {\overline{y}}&fg=000000$ to $latex {\overline{x}}&fg=000000$ only for a set $latex {\subset[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$ which captures a $latex {1-\epsilon}&fg=000000$ probability.
So if sequence Alice receives is $latex {\overline{X}=X_{1}X_{2}\cdots X_{k}}&fg=000000$, then the information she want to sent to Bob can be modelled by $latex {\overline{Y}=Y_{1}Y_{2}\cdots Y_{k}}&fg=000000$ where each $latex {Y_{i}}&fg=000000$'s are distributed in $latex {\mathcal{A}}&fg=000000$, such that $latex {\forall i,\Pr[X_{i}\in Y_{i}]=1\Leftrightarrow\Pr[\overline{X}\in\overline{Y}]=1}&fg=000000$. Also $latex { }&fg=000000$random variables $latex {X,Y}&fg=000000$ are said to confrom to the model if
  1. $latex {X}&fg=000000$ distributed in $latex {[n]}&fg=000000$ according to $latex {P}&fg=000000$
  2. $latex {Y}&fg=000000$ distributed in $latex {\mathcal{A}}&fg=000000$
  3. $latex {\Pr[X\in Y]=1}&fg=000000$

2. Naive Method

Divide the nodes of $latex {G}&fg=000000$ into independent sets (another way of saying colour $latex {G}&fg=000000$). If Alice saw $latex {i}&fg=000000$ which was in the independent set $latex {S}&fg=000000$, she sends $latex {S}&fg=000000$(or the colour of $latex {i}&fg=000000$). Let $latex {X}&fg=000000$ denote the random variable associated with the node and $latex {Y}&fg=000000$ be the colour of the node. Therefore the distribution $latex {P}&fg=000000$ on $latex {[n]}&fg=000000$ induces a distribution on the colours assigned and its entropy is given by $latex {H[Y]}&fg=000000$. Now Alice could sent the sequence of colours $latex {Y_{1}Y_{2}\cdots Y_{k}}&fg=000000$ encoded in bits using source coding. We know that for any constant $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$ error, best rate possible is $latex {H[Y]}&fg=000000$ from Shannon's Source Coding Theorem.

3. Better Method

Colour $latex {G^{k}}&fg=000000$ and choose the minimal set of colours such that it covers $latex {1-\epsilon}&fg=000000$ of the probability. Let

$latex \displaystyle N_{k}(G,\epsilon)=\min\left\{ l:\exists S_{1}S_{2}\cdots S_{l}\mbox{ which are independent sets of }G^{k}\mbox{ and }\Pr[\overline{X}\in\cup S_{i}]\geq1-\epsilon\right\} &fg=000000$

We will prove in section $latex {5}&fg=000000$ an upper bound of $latex {2^{kI[X:Y]+\circ(k)}}&fg=000000$ on $latex {N_{k}(G,\epsilon)}&fg=000000$(assuming that $latex {\overline{X}=X_{1}X_{2}\cdots X_{k}}&fg=000000$ and $latex {\overline{Y}=Y_{1}Y_{2}\cdots Y_{k}}&fg=000000$ are iid copies of some random variables $latex {X}&fg=000000$ and $latex {Y}&fg=000000$ that conforms with the model). Therefore the rate $latex {\lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}\frac{log_{2}N_{k}(G,\epsilon)}{k}\leq I[X:Y]=H[Y]-H[Y|X]\leq H[Y]}&fg=000000$ which was the rate by the naive method. Furthermore we can choose $latex {X}&fg=000000$ and $latex {Y}&fg=000000$ that conforms with the model such that $latex {I[X:Y]}&fg=000000$ is minimized, to reduce the rate to minimum. We will also prove(in next lecture) that one cannot do better than this.

4. Graph Entropy

The graph entropy of $latex {G}&fg=000000$ with respect to $latex {P}&fg=000000$ is defined as $latex {H(G,P)=\min I[X:Y]}&fg=000000$ where the minimization is over
  1. $latex {X}&fg=000000$ distributed in $latex {[n]}&fg=000000$ according to $latex {P}&fg=000000$
  2. $latex {Y}&fg=000000$ distributed in $latex {\mathcal{A}}&fg=000000$
  3. $latex {\Pr[X\in Y]=1}&fg=000000$
Note : There exists $latex {X,Y}&fg=000000$ which attains the minimum value of $latex {H(G,P)=I(X,Y)}&fg=000000$, since the minimization over a closed and bounded(also called compact) set. Sequences in compact set always converge. From the previous three sections, we have given $latex {H(G,P)}&fg=000000$ a particular meaning. That is, it is the best possible rate that can be achieved when some pairs of letters in transmitters side are not distinguishable.

5. Upper Bound

Claim : $latex {N_{k}(G,\epsilon)\leq2^{kH(G)+\circ(k)}}&fg=000000$ for all large $latex {k}&fg=000000$. Proof : Suppose $latex {X,Y}&fg=000000$ are such that $latex {I[X:Y]=H(G,P)}&fg=000000$, and $latex {\overline{X}=X_{1}X_{2}\cdots X_{k}}&fg=000000$,$latex {\overline{Y}=Y_{1}Y_{2}\cdots Y_{k}}&fg=000000$ be a sequence of iid copies of $latex {X,Y}&fg=000000$. $latex {\overline{X}}&fg=000000$ is distributed in $latex {[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$ according to $latex {P^{k}}&fg=000000$ and $latex {\overline{Y}}&fg=000000$ is distributed in $latex {\mathcal{A}^{k}}&fg=000000$ according to some distribution such that $latex {\forall i,\Pr[X_{i}\in Y_{i}]=1}&fg=000000$. Note that each sequence $latex {\overline{y}\in\mathcal{A}^{k}}&fg=000000$, can be thought of as an independent set $latex {S}&fg=000000$ of $latex {G^{k}}&fg=000000$(given by the mapping described in section $latex {1}&fg=000000$). Therefore $latex {\Pr[\overline{X}\in\overline{Y}]=\Pr[\forall i,X_{i}\in Y_{i}]=1}&fg=000000$. We know that the set of typical sequences in $latex {[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$ and $latex {\mathcal{A}^{k}}&fg=000000$ has sizes at most $latex {2^{kH[X]+\circ(k)}}&fg=000000$, $latex {2^{kH[Y]+\circ(k)}}&fg=000000$ respectively. For any fixed typical sequence $latex {\overline{x}\in[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$, given that $latex {\overline{X}=\overline{x}}&fg=000000$, the probability is concentrated mostly on $latex {2^{kH[Y|X]+\circ(k)}}&fg=000000$ elements in $latex { }&fg=000000$. Similarly for any fixed typical sequence $latex {\overline{y}\in\mathcal{A}^{k}}&fg=000000$, given that $latex {\overline{Y}=\overline{y}}&fg=000000$, the probability is concentrated mostly on $latex {2^{kH[X|Y]+\circ(k)}}&fg=000000$ elements in $latex {[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$. This can be considered as a regular bipartite graph. So we want to choose some $latex {t}&fg=000000$ elements of $latex {\mathcal{A}^{k}}&fg=000000$ such that, they capture $latex {1-\epsilon}&fg=000000$ probability in $latex {[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$. Suppose we are lucky that we get $latex {t}&fg=000000$ elements with disjoint neighbors, then $latex {t\leq2^{kH[X]-kH[X|Y]+\circ(k)}=2^{kH[G]+\circ(k)}}&fg=000000$. But this is not good enough for a proof. One way to do the proof is by carefully picking elements in $latex { }&fg=000000$ such that the neighbors set of the current pick intersects only with an $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$ mass in probability of the previously picked ones(See the proof of Channel Coding Theorem done by Jaikumar). Another way to do the proof is by randomly picking elements in $latex { }&fg=000000$. Suppose $latex {\overline{A}_{1},\overline{A}_{2},\cdots\overline{A}_{t}}&fg=000000$ are picked uniformly and independently from $latex {\mathcal{A}^{k}}&fg=000000$. Let $latex {D=2^{kH[Y|X]+\circ(k)}}&fg=000000$(the degree of $latex {\overline{x}\in[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$) and $latex {M=2^{kH[Y]+\circ(k)}}&fg=000000$, $latex {N(\overline{A}_{i})}&fg=000000$ denote the neighbors of $latex {\overline{A}_{i}}&fg=000000$, $latex {T}&fg=000000$ denote the typical sequences $latex {\subset[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$ . For any fixed $latex {\overline{x}\in\mbox{T}}&fg=000000$, $latex {\Pr[\overline{x}\notin\cup_{i}\mbox{N}(\overline{A}_{i})]\leq(1-D/M)^{t}\leq\exp(-tD/M)}&fg=000000$ (the second inequality is $latex {1+x\leq e^{x}}&fg=000000$). Therefore $latex {\Pr[\overline{X}\notin\cup_{i}\mbox{N}(\overline{A}_{i})|\overline{X}\in\mbox{T}]\leq\exp(-tD/M)}&fg=000000$.

$latex \Pr[\overline{X}\notin\cup_{i}\mbox{N}(\overline{A}_{i})] = \Pr[\overline{X}\in\mbox{T}]\Pr[\overline{X}\notin\cup_{i}\mbox{N}(\overline{A}_{i})|\overline{X}\in\mbox{T}]+\Pr[\overline{X}\notin\mbox{T}]\Pr[\overline{X}\notin\cup_{i}\mbox{N}(\overline{A}_{i})|\overline{X}\in\mbox{T}]\ \leq \exp(-tD/M)+\Pr[\overline{X}\notin\mbox{T}]$

Since $latex {\Pr[\overline{X}\notin\mbox{T}]}&fg=000000$ goes to $latex {0}&fg=000000$ as $latex {k\rightarrow\infty}&fg=000000$, it can be made arbitrarily small(say $latex {\epsilon/2}&fg=000000$) by taking large enough $latex {k}&fg=000000$. Also choose $latex {t=\frac{M}{D}\ln(2/\epsilon)}&fg=000000$, then we get $latex {\Pr[\overline{X}\notin\cup_{i}\mbox{N}(\overline{A}_{i})]\leq\epsilon}&fg=000000$. Note that for $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$ constant, $latex {t=2^{kI[X:Y]+constant+\circ(k)}}&fg=000000$. So we have proved that if we pick $latex {2^{kI[X:Y]+constant+\circ(k)}}&fg=000000$ elements in $latex {\mathcal{A}^{k}}&fg=000000$, uniformly and independently, the probability that they capture $latex {1-\epsilon}&fg=000000$ part(in probability) of sequences in $latex {[n]^{k}}&fg=000000$ goes to $latex {1}&fg=000000$ as $latex {k\rightarrow\infty}&fg=000000$. That is for large enough $latex {k}&fg=000000$, there exists one such code, which gives $latex {N_{k}(G,\epsilon)\leq2^{kH(G)+\circ(k)}}&fg=000000$.

item.title: Differential Entropy
item.dc:creator: girishvarma
item.content:encoded:
Lecture Notes from Jaikumar Radhakrishnan's Information Theory Course, scribed by me
  • $latex {X}&fg=000000$ : a real valued random variable
  • $latex {F(x)}&fg=000000$ : the distribution function of $latex {X}&fg=000000$
  • $latex {f(x)}&fg=000000$ : the density function of $latex {X}&fg=000000$
  • $latex {S}&fg=000000$: support of $latex {X}&fg=000000$
Consider the uniform distribution on $latex {[-1,1]}&fg=000000$ . This can be thought of as the limit distribution of a sequence of discrete uniform distributions. Entropy of each of this will be $latex {\log n}&fg=000000$ and so entropy goes to infinity. So this definition of entropy doesn't suffice.
Definition : The differential entropy of a real valued random variable $latex {X}&fg=000000$ is defined as $latex {h[X]=-\int_{S}f(x)\log_{2}f(x)dx}&fg=000000$ .
If $latex {X}&fg=000000$ is uniform on $latex {[0,a]}&fg=000000$ then $latex {h[X]=\log a}&fg=000000$. Therefore $latex {h[X]}&fg=000000$ increases as $latex {a}&fg=000000$ increases, which is resonable for an entropy function. For a normal distribution with $latex {f(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^{2}}}e^{-x^{2}/2\sigma^{2}}}&fg=000000$, $latex {h[X]=\frac{1}{2}\log2\pi e\sigma^{2}}&fg=000000$, that is $latex {h[X]}&fg=000000$ increases as the normal distribution is flatter.

1. Asymptotic Equipartition Property

Theorem : $latex {X_{1},X_{2}\cdots X_{k}}&fg=000000$ are iid's with density function $latex {f(x)}&fg=000000$, and $latex {f(x_{1},x_{2},\cdots x_{k})=f(x_{1})f(x_{2})\cdots f(x_{k})}&fg=000000$ then

$latex \displaystyle \begin{array}{rcl} -\frac{1}{k}\log f(X_{1},X_{2}\cdots X_{k})=-\frac{1}{k}\sum_{i}\log f(X_{i})\overset{\mbox{in prob}}{\longrightarrow}\mathbb{E}[-\log f(X)]=h[X]\\ ie\ \lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}\Pr\left[\left|-\frac{1}{k}\log f(X_{1},X_{2}\cdots X_{k})-h[X]\right|>\epsilon\right] & = & 0\\ ie\ \forall(\epsilon,\delta),\ \exists k_{0},\ \forall k>k_{0},\Pr\left[\left|-\frac{1}{k}\log f(X_{1},X_{2}\cdots X_{k})-h[X]\right|>\epsilon\right] & < & \delta\end{array} &fg=000000$

Proof: A simple application of weak law of large numbers by considering the random variable $latex {Y=-\log f(X)}&fg=000000$ will imply the theorem. The theorem says that if we consider iid samples of $latex {Y}&fg=000000$ , the sample average converges in probability to the $latex {\mathbb{E}[Y]}&fg=000000$ which is exactly what WLLN says.$latex \Box&fg=000000$
Theorem For any fixed $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$, let $latex {A(k,\epsilon)=\{\overline{x}\in S^{k}:\left|-\frac{1}{k}\log f(\overline{x})-h[X]\right|\leq\epsilon\}}&fg=000000$(above says that probability of this event can be made arbitrarily large) then for all large $latex {k}&fg=000000$, 1. $latex {\Pr[A(k,\epsilon)]\geq1-\epsilon}&fg=000000$ 2. $latex {(1-\epsilon)2^{k(h[X]-\epsilon)}\leq volume(A(k,\epsilon))\leq2^{k(h[X]+\epsilon)}}&fg=000000$
Proof: 1. is true from the previous theorem by putting $latex {\epsilon=\delta}&fg=000000$. From definition of $latex {A(k,\epsilon)}&fg=000000$ $latex {\forall\overline{x}\in A(k,\epsilon),2^{-k(h[X]+\epsilon)}\leq f(\overline{x})\leq2^{-k(h[X]-\epsilon)}}&fg=000000$ and from 1. $latex {1-\epsilon\leq\int_{A(k,\epsilon)}f(\overline{x})dx\leq1}&fg=000000$ which directly imply 2.$latex \Box&fg=000000$
Theorem $latex {A(k,\epsilon)}&fg=000000$ is the smallest volume set that captures $latex {1-\epsilon}&fg=000000$ of the probability to first order in the exponent. ie any set $latex {B}&fg=000000$ with $latex {volume(B)\leq2^{k(h[X]-\delta)}}&fg=000000$ cannot have $latex {\Pr[B]\geq1-\epsilon}&fg=000000$ for large enough $latex {k}&fg=000000$.
Proof: Let $latex {B}&fg=000000$ be such that $latex {\Pr[B]\geq1-\epsilon}&fg=000000$, then $latex {\Pr[B\cap A(k,\delta/10)]\geq1-\epsilon-\delta/10}&fg=000000$. But since all $latex {\overline{x}}&fg=000000$ in this set has $latex {f(\overline{x})\geq2^{-k(h[X]+\delta/10)}}&fg=000000$, $latex {volume(B\cap A(k,\delta/10))\times2^{-k(h[X]+\delta/10)}\geq1-\epsilon-\delta/10}&fg=000000$. That is $latex {volume(B)\geq(1-\epsilon-\delta/10)2^{k(h[X]+\delta/10)}}&fg=000000$ $latex \Box&fg=000000$

2. Quantization : An Operational Meaning for $latex {h[X]}&fg=000000$

Suppose Alice observes $latex {X}&fg=000000$, and she wants to communicate this value with some precision $latex {\Delta}&fg=000000$ (to Bob ofcourse). So we slice the support of $latex {X}&fg=000000$ into pieces of size $latex {\Delta}&fg=000000$. By Mean Value theorem we know that $latex {\exists x_{i}}&fg=000000$ in slice $latex {i}&fg=000000$ such that $latex {\Delta f(x_{i})=}&fg=000000$ the integral of $latex {f}&fg=000000$ in slice $latex {i}&fg=000000$. Define $latex {p(x_{i})=\Delta f(x_{i})}&fg=000000$, which is a discrete distribution. $latex {H(p)=-\sum_{i}\Delta f(x_{i})\log\Delta f(x_{i})=-\sum_{i}\Delta f(x_{i})\log\Delta f(x_{i})-\log\Delta}&fg=000000$. As $latex {\Delta}&fg=000000$ goes to $latex {0}&fg=000000$, this becomes $latex {h[X]-\log\Delta}&fg=000000$. That is if Alice wants to communicate with more prescision(smaller $latex {\Delta}&fg=000000$), she needs more bits. Note that if $latex {X}&fg=000000$ is uniform on $latex {[0,1/8]}&fg=000000$, and Alice want to communicate at a presicion of $latex {n}&fg=000000$ bits (ie $latex {\Delta=2^{-n}}&fg=000000$), she just needs to sent $latex {h[X]-\log\Delta=-3+n}&fg=000000$ bits. This coincides with the fact that since the interval is of length $latex {1/8}&fg=000000$, the first $latex {3}&fg=000000$ bits will be $latex {0}&fg=000000$'s. So she doesn't have to sent it.

item.title: Pseudorandomness for Width 2 Branching Programs and Small Degree Polynomials
item.dc:creator: girishvarma
item.content:encoded:
Lecture Notes from Nutan Limaye's Small Space Computaions Course, presented and scribed by me. This is the summary of a paper by Andrej Bogdanov, Zeev Dvir, Elad Verbin and Amir Yehudayoff.

1. About Derandomization

Let $latex {\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$ be a class of languages($latex {\subset\{0,1\}^{*}}&fg=000000$) that can be decided by some model of computation deterministically given some complexity bounds. Then we can define the class $latex {R\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$ which makes use of randomization as follows. Lets say the model takes an auxilary input $latex {r\in\left\{ 0,1\right\} ^{m}}&fg=000000$. For any $latex {x}&fg=000000$, and $latex {r}&fg=000000$ choosen uniformly at random, the probability that the model correctly answers whether $latex {x\in L}&fg=000000$ is very high (say $latex {\geq2/3}&fg=000000$). Now the we ask ``Is there any point in doing this?'' or ``Is $latex {R\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$=$latex {\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$?''. One way of trying to prove $latex {R\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$=$latex {\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$ is to come up with a function $latex {G:\{0,1\}^{t}\rightarrow\{0,1\}^{m},t<<m}&fg=000000$ and replace the uniformly random string by the output of this function on a uniformly random input. Now It needs to proved that this will not affect the bound on success probability and $latex {G}&fg=000000$ itself should be computable in $latex {\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$. Note that here we are attempting to decrease the true randomness used. But if $latex {t}&fg=000000$ is very small, then by doing a brute force search over all $latex {t}&fg=000000$'s(accept if the algo accepts for large number of $latex {t}&fg=000000$'s) we can completely get rid of randomness. Such functions are called pseudorandom generators(or PRNG's). Such proofs that randomness doen't give additional power, are said to derandomize $latex {\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$.
Definition : A distribution $latex {D}&fg=000000$ on $latex {\{0,1\}^{n}}&fg=000000$ is said to be $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom(or PR in short) against a class $latex {\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$ of functions $latex {f:\{0,1\}^{n}\rightarrow\{0,1\}}&fg=000000$ iff $latex {\forall f\in\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$

$latex \displaystyle \left|\Pr_{x\leftarrow D}[f(x)=1]-\Pr_{x\leftarrow U_{n}}[f(x)=1]\right|\leq\epsilon&fg=000000$

where $latex {U_{n}}&fg=000000$ is the uniform distribution on $latex {\{0,1\}^{n}}&fg=000000$. $latex {G:\{0,1\}^{m}\rightarrow\{0,1\}^{n}}&fg=000000$ is $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom against a class $latex {\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$ iff $latex {G(U_{m})}&fg=000000$ is $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom against a class $latex {\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$. Note that if $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$ is smaller, it is better(well thats why its called $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$).
$latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$-pseudorandomness of $latex {G}&fg=000000$ will imply that the probability of success of algorithms in $latex {R\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$ will remain bounded when random string is choosen according to $latex {G(U_{m})}&fg=000000$. We say simply that there is a pseodorandom generator for $latex {\mathfrak{C}}&fg=000000$, when there is one with a very small $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$(say $latex {e^{-poly(n)}}&fg=000000$).

2. Derandomization of Small Space Computations

Now we are interested in the question is $latex {RL=L}&fg=000000$? Lots of efforts are on in proving this, and one major result known due to Reingold is that UREACH(Undirected Reachability) can be done in $latex {L}&fg=000000$. It was known that UREACH can be done in $latex {RL}&fg=000000$. Moreover UREACH is a complete problem for a class $latex {SL\subset RL}&fg=000000$ that contained other interesting problems. So Reingold effectively proved $latex {SL=L}&fg=000000$. The proof used pseodorandom generators. Another result known is $latex {RSPACE(\log n)\subset DSPACE(\log^{3/2}n)}&fg=000000$, which used a pseudorandom generator by Nissan to simulate the randomized computation in determistic space. A second way of investigating the question is by asking the same for simpler classes like $latex {NC^{1}}&fg=000000$, branching programs with particular parameters, polynomials of small degree. Recently Bogdanov,Viola, Lovett constructed pseudorandom generators for degree $latex {k}&fg=000000$ polynomials, by suming $latex {k}&fg=000000$ independent copies of a pseudorandom generator for degree $latex {1}&fg=000000$ polynomials. This paper tries to understand the limitations of this method. Positive result is that PRNG's for degree $latex {k}&fg=000000$ also work well for $latex {(k,t,n)}&fg=000000$-2BP's(ie width $latex {2}&fg=000000$, depth $latex {t}&fg=000000$, branching programs that read $latex {k}&fg=000000$ bits at a time on $latex {n}&fg=000000$ inputs).

3. PRNG's for degree $latex {k}&fg=000000$ polynomials also works for width $latex {2}&fg=000000$ BP's which read $latex {k}&fg=000000$ bits at a time

Definition : $latex {(k,t,n)}&fg=000000$-$latex {w}&fg=000000$BP(Branching Program) is a layered DAG, with $latex {t}&fg=000000$ layers, $latex {w}&fg=000000$ nodes at each layer, edges always go from one layer to the next. For every node there are $latex {2^{k}}&fg=000000$ edges going to the next layer each labelled by a $latex {k}&fg=000000$ bit string and each layer is assigned some $latex {k}&fg=000000$ bit positions in input $latex {x\in\{0,1\}^{n}}&fg=000000$ denoting which edge to take on $latex {x}&fg=000000$. The first node in the first layer is labelled start and final layer has only $latex {2}&fg=000000$ nodes labelled accept and reject. So each input $latex {x}&fg=000000$ will represent a unique path from start to accept or reject node. A function $latex {f:\{0,1\}^{n}\rightarrow\{0,1\}}&fg=000000$ is said to be computed by a branching program, if $latex {f(x)=1}&fg=000000$ iff the branching program ends in an accept node on input $latex {x}&fg=000000$. A $latex {(k,t,n)}&fg=000000$-$latex {w}&fg=000000$BP is read once if the input is read in the right order, ie if $latex {\overline{x}_{1},\overline{x}_{2},\cdots,\overline{x}_{t}}&fg=000000$ denotes the block of bits of length $latex {k}&fg=000000$ each read at the corresponding layers, then $latex {x=\overline{x}_{1}\cdot\overline{x}_{2}\cdots\overline{x}_{t}}&fg=000000$.
Theorem 1 : If $latex {D}&fg=000000$ is $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom for polynomials of degree $latex {k}&fg=000000$, then it is $latex {\epsilon t}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom for $latex {(k,t,n)}&fg=000000$-$latex {2}&fg=000000$BP's
Proof : We express functions computed by width 2 BP's that read $latex {k}&fg=000000$ bits, as a {}``higher order sum'' of degree $latex {k}&fg=000000$ polynomials with sum of absolute values of coefficients bounded. Next claim proves that this implies Theorem 2. Claim : : If $latex {f:\{0,1\}^{n}\rightarrow\{0,1\}}&fg=000000$ is such that
  1. $latex {f(x)=\sum_{\mathbf{\mbox{all polynomials }\mathbf{g}_{\mathbf{i}}\mbox{of degree }}k}\alpha_{i}g_{i}(x)}&fg=000000$ (this is a ``higher order sum'' ie sum is over reals and $latex {\alpha_{i}\in\mathbb{R}}&fg=000000$)
  2. $latex {\sum_{i}|\alpha_{i}|\leq L}&fg=000000$
and $latex {G:\{0,1\}^{m}\rightarrow\{0,1\}^{n}}&fg=000000$ is $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom against degree $latex {k}&fg=000000$ polynomials then $latex {D}&fg=000000$ is $latex {\epsilon L}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom against $latex {f}&fg=000000$. Note that if $latex {\hat{f}(x)=(-1)^{f(x)}}&fg=000000$ then $latex {\mathbb{E}_{D}[\hat{f}(x)]=1-2\Pr_{D}[f(x)=1]}&fg=000000$. We do this to use the linearity property of expectation and also independence properties of the distribution $latex {D}&fg=000000$.

$latex \displaystyle \begin{array}{rcl} 2\cdot\left|\Pr_{x\leftarrow U_{n}}[f(x)=1]-\Pr_{s\leftarrow U_{m}}[f(G(s))=1]\right| & = & \left|\mathbb{E}_{U_{n},U_{m}}[\hat{f}(G(s))-\hat{f}(x)]\right|\\ & \leq & \sum_{i}|\alpha_{i}|\cdot\left|\mathbb{E}_{U_{n},U_{m}}[\hat{g}(G(s))-\hat{g}(x)]\right|\\ & = & \sum_{i}|\alpha_{i}|\cdot2\cdot\left|\Pr_{x\leftarrow U_{n}}[f(x)=1]-\Pr_{s\leftarrow U_{m}}[f(G(s))=1]\right|\\ & \leq & 2\cdot t\cdot\epsilon\end{array} &fg=000000$

Claim : If $latex {f:\{0,1\}^{n}\rightarrow\{0,1\}}&fg=000000$ is computed by a $latex {(k,t,n)-2}&fg=000000$BP then $latex {f}&fg=000000$ can be written as
  1. $latex {f(x)=\sum_{\mathbf{\mbox{all polynomials }\mathbf{g}_{\mathbf{i}}\mbox{of degree }}k}\alpha_{i}g_{i}(x)}&fg=000000$ (this is a {}``higher order sum'' ie sum is over reals and $latex {\alpha_{i}\in\mathbb{R}}&fg=000000$)
  2. $latex {\sum_{i}|\alpha_{i}|\leq t}&fg=000000$
Proof is by induction on $latex {t}&fg=000000$. Base Case : For $latex {t=1}&fg=000000$, $latex {f}&fg=000000$ is clearly a degree $latex {k}&fg=000000$ polynomial. Inductive Step : Let the function computed by the BP at layer $latex {t-1}&fg=000000$ be $latex {f_{|t-1}(x)}&fg=000000$. Then

$latex \displaystyle f(x)=P(f_{|t-1}(x),\overline{x}_{t-1})&fg=000000$

where $latex {\overline{x}_{t-1}}&fg=000000$ is the block of bits read by the BP at layer $latex {t-1}&fg=000000$ and $latex {P}&fg=000000$ is the mapping that the branching program does for evaluating the position in the next level ie $latex {f(x)}&fg=000000$. It can be proved that there exists functions $latex {A,B:\{0,1\}^{k}\rightarrow\{0,1\}}&fg=000000$ such that

$latex \displaystyle \hat{P}(z,y)=A(y)\cdot(-1)^{z}+B(y)&fg=000000$

It will follow that $latex {A(y)=\frac{1}{2}(\hat{P}(0,y)-\hat{P}(1,y))}&fg=000000$ and $latex {B(y)=\frac{1}{2}(\hat{P}(0,y)+\hat{P}(1,y))}&fg=000000$. That is $latex {\forall z\in\{0,1\},y\in\{0,1\}^{k}}&fg=000000$,

$latex \displaystyle \hat{f}(x)=\hat{P}(f_{|t-1}(x),y)=\frac{1}{2}(\hat{P}(0,y)-\hat{P}(1,y))\cdot\hat{f}_{|t-1}(x)+\frac{1}{2}(\hat{P}(0,y)+\hat{P}(1,y))&fg=000000$

From this we can apply the inductive hypothesis that $latex {\hat{f}{}_{|t-1}(x)}&fg=000000$ can be written as a higher order sum of degree $latex {k}&fg=000000$ polynomials with sum of modulus of coefficient $latex {\leq t-1}&fg=000000$. It can be verified that this will give a higher order sum for $latex {\hat{f}}&fg=000000$ such that sum of modulus of coefficients is $latex {\leq t}&fg=000000$. Only thing to notice here is the fact that $latex {\hat{h}(x)=\hat{g}(x)\cdot\hat{p}(x)}&fg=000000$ iff $latex {h(x)=g(x)\oplus p(x)}&fg=000000$.

4. PR for degree $latex {k}&fg=000000$ polynomials does not imply PR for width $latex {3}&fg=000000$ read once BP

This is true due to Widgerson, Viola's result that uniform distribution over set of strings which has number of $latex {1}&fg=000000$'s a multiple of $latex {3}&fg=000000$, is pseudorandom for degree $latex {k}&fg=000000$ polynomials. But this set of string's can easily be identified by read once $latex {3}&fg=000000$BP.
Theorem 2 :There exists a distribution $latex {D}&fg=000000$ on $latex {\{0,1\}^{n}}&fg=000000$ that is $latex {e^{-\alpha n/4^{k}}}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom against degree $latex {k}&fg=000000$ polynomials but not $latex {0.66}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom for $latex {(1,n,n)-3}&fg=000000$BP that is read-once.
Proof: Let $latex {mod_{3}(x)=\omega^{\sum x_{i}}}&fg=000000$ where $latex {\omega}&fg=000000$ is the cube root of unity and $latex {D}&fg=000000$ be the distribution that is uniform over $latex {\{x:mod_{3}(x)=1\}}&fg=000000$. A result by Viola and Widgerson implies that $latex {D}&fg=000000$ is $latex {e^{-\alpha n/4^{k}}}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom against degree $latex {k}&fg=000000$ polynomials. Now consider the function $latex {f(x)=1}&fg=000000$ iff $latex {mod_{3}(x)=1}&fg=000000$. This function is clearly computable by a $latex {(1,n,n)-3}&fg=000000$BP that is read-once. It is true that $latex {\mathbb{E}_{D}[f(x)]=1}&fg=000000$. Since whenever $latex {f(x)=1}&fg=000000$, $latex {mod(x)=1}&fg=000000$

$latex \displaystyle \mathbb{E}_{U_{n}}[f(x)]=\frac{1}{3}\mathbb{E}_{U_{n}}[1+mod_{3}(x)+mod_{3}(x)^{2}]&fg=000000$

Now we can make use of independence of each bit of $latex {U_{n}}&fg=000000$. For $latex {a\in\{1,2\}}&fg=000000$,

$latex \displaystyle \left|\mathbb{E}_{U_{n}}[mod_{3}(x)^{a}]\right|=\left|(\mathbb{E}_{x_{1}\leftarrow U_{1}}[\omega^{ax_{1}}])^{n}\right|=\left|\left(\frac{1+\omega^{a}}{2}\right)^{n}\right|=2^{-n}&fg=000000$

Therefore $latex {\mathbb{E}_{U_{n}}[f(x)]=\frac{1}{3}+\frac{2^{-n+1}}{3}\leq0.34}&fg=000000$. That is $latex {D}&fg=000000$ is not $latex {0.66}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom for $latex {(1,n,n)-3}&fg=000000$BP that is read-once. $latex \Box&fg=000000$

5. Viola's Construction doesn't work for width $latex {5}&fg=000000$ BP's

Theorem 3 : For every $latex {n,\epsilon,k}&fg=000000$ such that $latex {k\log(1/\epsilon)<\sqrt{n/2}-1,}&fg=000000$ $latex {\exists}&fg=000000$ $latex {D}&fg=000000$ a distribution that is $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom for degree $latex {1}&fg=000000$ polynomials(on $latex {\{0,1\}^{n}}&fg=000000$) such that $latex {D^{k}}&fg=000000$ the distribution obtained by summing $latex {k}&fg=000000$ independent samples from $latex {D}&fg=000000$, is not $latex {1/3}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom for width 5 branching programs(on $latex {\{0,1\}^{n}}&fg=000000$).
Proof : The basic idea behind the proof is that computing the rank of a matrix can be done with $latex {(1,t,n)}&fg=000000$-$latex {5}&fg=000000$BP. So we construct a distribution keeping this in mind. Consider the following distribution on $latex {\{0,1\}^{n}}&fg=000000$. For $latex {m=k\log(1/\epsilon)+1}&fg=000000$, partition $latex {x}&fg=000000$ into $latex {n/m}&fg=000000$ blocks $latex {\overline{x}_{1},\overline{x}_{2},\cdots\overline{x}_{n/m}}&fg=000000$ each of size $latex {m}&fg=000000$. Now
  1. Choose a random subspace $latex {S}&fg=000000$, of $latex {\mathbb{F}_{2}^{m}}&fg=000000$ of dimension $latex {\frac{m-1}{k}}&fg=000000$.
  2. Pick $latex {\overline{x}_{i}}&fg=000000$'s independently and uniformly from $latex {S}&fg=000000$.
Claim : $latex {D}&fg=000000$ is $latex {\epsilon}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom for degree $latex {1}&fg=000000$ polynomials. Any degree $latex {1}&fg=000000$ polynomial can be thought of as a dot product of input with a particular bit string. Let $latex {a(x)=<a\cdot x>}&fg=000000$ be a degree $latex {1}&fg=000000$ polynomial. Since we have partitioned $latex {x}&fg=000000$ into blocks in defining $latex {D}&fg=000000$, we will do the same for $latex {a}&fg=000000$. That is let $latex {a(x)=\left\langle a\cdot x\right\rangle =\sum_{i=1}^{n/m}\left\langle a_{i}\cdot\overline{x}_{i}\right\rangle }&fg=000000$ where $latex {a_{i}}&fg=000000$ is the $latex {i}&fg=000000$th block of $latex {a}&fg=000000$ with length $latex {m}&fg=000000$.

$latex \displaystyle \mathbb{E}_{D}[(-1){}^{a(x)}]=\mathbb{E}_{S}[\prod_{i=1}^{n/m}\mathbb{E}_{\overline{x}_{i}\leftarrow S}[(-1)^{\left\langle a_{i}\cdot\overline{x}_{i}\right\rangle }]]&fg=000000$

That is we are randomly choosing $latex {S}&fg=000000$ and conditioned on $latex {S}&fg=000000$, we are randomly choosing $latex {x\in S}&fg=000000$. Since $latex {\overline{x}_{i}}&fg=000000$'s are independent samples from $latex {S}&fg=000000$, the expectation splits into product of expectations. Now $latex {\mathbb{E}_{\overline{x}_{i}\leftarrow S}[(-1)^{\left\langle a_{i}\cdot\overline{x}_{i}\right\rangle }]=1}&fg=000000$ if $latex {a_{i}\in S^{\perp}}&fg=000000$. It can be proved with little effort that $latex {\mathbb{E}_{\overline{x}_{i}\leftarrow S}[(-1)^{\left\langle a_{i}\cdot\overline{x}_{i}\right\rangle }]=0}&fg=000000$ if $latex {a_{i}\notin S^{\perp}}&fg=000000$. So

$latex \displaystyle \mathbb{E}_{D}[(-1){}^{a(x)}]=\Pr_{S}[\forall i,\ a_{i}\in S^{\perp}]\leq\Pr_{S}[a_{1}\in S^{\perp}]=\Pr_{S^{\perp}}[a_{1}\in S^{\perp}]=2^{m-(m-1)/k}/2^{m}=\frac{1}{2^{(m-1)/k}}=\epsilon&fg=000000$

Therefore $latex {\left|\mathbb{E}_{D}[a(x)]-\mathbb{E}_{U}[a(x)]\right|=\left|\mathbb{E}_{D}[a(x)]-1/2\right|=\epsilon/2<\epsilon}&fg=000000$. Claim : $latex {D^{k}}&fg=000000$ is not $latex {1/3}&fg=000000$-pseudorandom for width $latex {5}&fg=000000$ branching programs that read $latex {1}&fg=000000$ bit at a time. Let $latex {X=X_{1}+X_{2}\cdots+X_{k}}&fg=000000$ where $latex {X_{i}}&fg=000000$'s are independent samples from $latex {D}&fg=000000$. Let $latex {S_{1},S_{2}\cdots S_{k}}&fg=000000$ be the subspaces from which the blocks of each of the samples was chosen. Therefore each block of $latex {X}&fg=000000$ lies in the subspace $latex {S_{1}+S_{2}\cdots+S_{k}}&fg=000000$ which has dimension $latex {m-1}&fg=000000$ (since each $latex {S_{i}}&fg=000000$ has dimension $latex {(m-1)/k}&fg=000000$). Suppose $latex {n}&fg=000000$ is large such that $latex {\frac{n}{m}>2m}&fg=000000$. Now consider the $latex {m\times2m}&fg=000000$ matrix with the blocks as columns. The rank of this matrix is definitely $latex {\leq m-1}&fg=000000$ if the sample is from $latex {D^{k}}&fg=000000$. If the sample is from uniform, all entries of the matrix are random bits. So we have $latex {m}&fg=000000$ number of $latex {2m}&fg=000000$ bit strings each randomly chosen. Suppose it is chosen in the order of rows of the matrix. $latex {\Pr[\mbox{matrix is not full rank}]\leq\sum_{i=1}^{m}\Pr[i\mbox{th choice was linearly dependent to previous}]=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{m}2^{i-1}}{2^{2m}}\leq\frac{1}{2^{m}}}&fg=000000$

item.title: I wish I could
item.dc:creator: girishvarma
item.content:encoded: The image of my grandfather comes to my mind. A person who lived in a time when nothing was certain. He raised his family of 6 children and all of them has enough to live peacefully . A farmer who could not stop working even during his last days. I can never imagine him being angry. He had a very young heart. He used to follow cricket tournaments even when he was old. When ms dhoni started his career in the Indian cricket team, grandpa was immediately impressed by him. I remember him saying "people like dhoni should lead the team". Compared to his times I live in affluene, with a certain future(even in a worst case I think I will still get some job).His life (and I guess) his ambitions were simple yet he worked hard. I wish to become some great scientist but still I am lazy, and wasting life worrying about silly things. A sense of duty engulfs me now, but I don't know how long it will last.

item.title: Amortized Lowerbound for DYCK
item.dc:creator: girishvarma
item.content:encoded:
Definition(Randomized $latex t$-jobs Algorithm with One-sided Error for $latex DYCK_2$) A randomized algorithm $latex A$ is said to be randomized $latex t$-jobs algorithm with one-sided error for $latex DYCK_2$ iff the following properties are satisfied
  • its input is of the form $latex (x_1,x_2,\cdots x_t)$ where each $latex x_i$ is an instance of $latex DYCK_2$ of the same length(say $latex N$)
  • if $latex \forall i \in [t],~ x_i \in DYCK_2$ then $latex \Pr[A(x_1,x_2,\cdots x_t) = 1] = 1$
  • if $latex \exists i \in [t], ~ x_i \notin DYCK_2$ then $latex \Pr[A(x_1,x_2,\cdots x_t) = 1] \leq e$ where $latex e$ is a constant $latex < 1$
Theorem : $latex \forall \alpha \in (0,1),~ t\in \mathbb{N}$ any randomized $latex t$-jobs algorithm with one-sided error for $latex DYCK_2$ will require space $latex \Omega(t \sqrt{N} )$ after reading the first $latex \lfloor \alpha N \rfloor $ part of each of the $latex t$ instances. Proof : We will define a communication problem $latex T-JOBS-ASC(t,m,n)$ which is $latex t$ copies of the problem $latex ASCENSION(m,n)$ run in parallel using the same players. We will prove a direct sum result which gives that the IC(information cost) for former is $latex t$ times the latter. Since we already know a $latex \Omega(m\log n)$ lower bound for the IC of $latex ASCENSION(m,n)$ from [MMN], this gives that the information cost of $latex T-JOBS-ASC(t,m,n)$ is $latex \Omega(tm\log n)$. Then we will give a reduction in which an algorithm $latex A$, that satisfies the theorem for a particular $latex \alpha$, running on inputs of size $latex N$ satisfying $latex \lfloor \alpha N \rfloor = 3mn$, is used to give a communication protocol for $latex \text{T}-\text{JOBS}-\text{ASC}(t,m,n)$ such that the $latex IC(P) \leq s(N)$ where $latex s(N)$ is the space used by the algorithm after seeing $latex \alpha N$ alphabets of the input. This gives that $latex s(N) \geq tn$ for $latex m=n/\log n$ and $latex N = 3n^2 / \alpha \log n \Rightarrow n = \Omega(\sqrt{N})$. Hence the theorem follows. Definition ($latex \text{T}-\text{JOBS}-\text{ASC}(t,m,n)$): It is a communication problem involving $latex t$ instances of $latex ASCENSION(m,n)$. Formally
  • It has $latex 2m$ players $latex A_i,B_i ~ i\in [m]$
  • $latex \forall i \in [m]$ each $latex A_i$ has $latex X_{ij} \in \{0,1\}^n ~ j \in [t]$, each $latex B_i$ has $latex Y_{ij},k_{ij},c_{ij}~j\in [t]$ where $latex k_{ij} \in [n], c_{ij} \in \{0,1\}, Y_{ij} = X_{ij}[1,k_{ij}-1]$
  • The communication pattern similar to $latex ASCENSION(m,n)$
  • The objective is to compute the function $latex f(X,k,c) = \bigvee _{i\in [m]. j \in [t]} f(X_{ij},k_{ij},c_{ij})$ where $latex f(X_{ij},k_{ij},c_{ij}) = X_{ij}[k_{ij}]\oplus c_{ij}$.
The information cost of a protocol $latex P$ with respect to a distribution $latex \mu$ on $latex X,k,c$ is defined as $latex IC_{\mu}(P) = I[k,c:M_{B_m}|X,R] = \sum_{i=1}^t I[k_i,c_i: M_{B_m}| X,R,k_{1},k_{2},\cdots k_{i-1} ,c_{1},c_{2},\cdots c_{i-1}]$ where $latex k_i = (k_{1i},k_{2i},\cdots k_{mi})$. Claim:$latex IC_{\mu_0}^{pub}(\text{T-JOBS-ASC}(t,m,n),\delta ) \geq t IC^{pub}_{\mu_0}(ASCENSION(m,n),\delta)$ where $latex \mu_0$ is the uniform distribution in the set of inputs with the objective function value 0. Proof: This follows exactly the same way as the proof given in the [MMN STOC PAPER]. Theorem[MMN]: $latex IC^{pub}_{\mu_0}(ASCENSION(m,n),1/42n^2) = \Omega(m\log n)$ From above two we deduce $latex IC^{pub}_{\mu_0}(T-JOBS-ASC(t,m,n), 1/42n^2) = \Omega(tm\log n)$ Reduction from $latex T-JOBS-ASC(t,m,n)$ to the algorithm Note: the reduction works only for $latex \alpha \leq 3/4$. But one can easily make a similar argument for $latex \alpha > 3/4$. Basically it involves construction of a $latex DYCK_2$ instance from an instance for $latex ASCENSION(m,n)$, of length $latex 4mn$ with $latex 3mn$ is an uphill part(in the hard instance given in [MMN STOC PAPER]) and $latex mn$ length down hill part. By setting $latex \alpha N = 3mn$ we make sure that the uphill is aligned exactly to the position $latex \alpha N$. The rest of the part is filled with dummy string of matched opening and closing brackets. And we have proved a lowerbound for the information transfered at this point, which gives the result. From $latex t$ instances of $latex ASCENSION(m,n)$ in $latex t-JOBS-ASC$ we make $latex t$ instances of $latex DYCK_2$ of size $latex N=3mn/\alpha$ as follows. Fix $latex j \in [t]$, $latex X_{1j}$ is converted to a corresponding sequence of opening brackets in the reverse order, $latex Y_{1j}$ is converted to a corresponding sequence of closing brackets followed by the corresponding closing bracket for $latex c_{1j}$(this is exactly similar to what is done in [MMN STOC PAPER]). Now the next $latex 2(n-k_{1j})$ length substring is set as $latex (^{n-k_{1j}} )^{n-k_{1j}}$ which is a dummy string. The next alphabet is set as the corresponding opening bracket for $latex c_{1j}$, followed by corresponding sequence of opening brackets for $latex Y_{1j}$ in the reverse order. Here we have differed from [MMN STOC PAPER], since we want an exact $latex 3n$ length string. Thus we finish the encoding of inputs in the hands of $latex A_1$ and $latex B_1$. We repeat this $latex \forall i \in [m]$ in increasing order to get a string of length $latex 3mn$ which corresponds to the string till the top of the hill in the diagram. Now we add another $latex mn$ length string which is the corresponding sequence of closing brackets of $latex X_{ij}$ for each $latex i \in [m]$ starting from $latex m$ in the decreasing order. So by now we will have got a $latex 4mn = \frac{4}{3}\alpha N$ length string. The rest of the $latex (1-\frac{4}{3}\alpha) N$ length string is filled with some dummy string of opening and closing brackets(Since $latex N$ is of even lenght for a $latex DYCK_2$ string, and the string we constructed is also of even length, the remaining part should be even length). This is done for each $latex j \in [t]$ to get $latex t$ instances of $latex DYCK_2$. Now $latex A_1$ runs the algorithm on the first $latex n$ alphabets and passes the its memory to $latex B_1$ who runs it on the next $latex 2n$ alphabets. We keep doing the same untill $latex B_m$ finishes running the algorithm on the $latex 3mn$th alphabet. Then he passes it down to $latex A_m$ and it reaches down the the obivous way till $latex A_1$ each whom will run the algorithm on the next $latex n$ alphabets. Besides this, in the end $latex A_1$ will also have to run the algorithm on $latex (1-\frac{4}{3}\alpha) N$ length dummy string of a matched sequence of brackets, and after that she declares the output.

item.title: The Markov Chain Monte Carlo(MCMC) Method
item.dc:creator: girishvarma
item.content:encoded:
If you have a deck of cards, and you want to make the arrangement random, what do you do? You shuffle it. Lets look at this in a more formal setting. The deck of cards can be thought of as an ordered set $latex {[n]}&fg=000000$. There is some initial arrangement of cards, which correspond to an initial permutation in $latex {S_{n}}&fg=000000$(the set of all permutations on $latex {[n]}&fg=000000$). Then you do some random modification to the permutation by the ``shuffle'' procedure. And you keep on doing this. Notice that ``shuffle'' is a simple procedure that is always done the same way, without taking into account what the previous permutation was. And we hope that after sometime we get a random permutation. There is a formal proof which says that $latex {7}&fg=000000$ riffle shuffles will give you a permutation that is close to random by Persi Diaconis and David Aldous. This can be thought of in a more general setting. Suppose we have a set $latex {S}&fg=000000$, and given an arbitrary element of $latex {S}&fg=000000$ we want to generate a random element of $latex {S}&fg=000000$ according to some distribution. Mostly $latex {S}&fg=000000$ is not known explicitly and it can be of very large size. ie $latex {S}&fg=000000$ may be the set of perfect matchings of a graph. So we can take an element in $latex {S}&fg=000000$ and do some simple random modification(like the shuffle) and keep doing this. The random modification can be thought of as a graph with vertex set $latex {S}&fg=000000$, with edges from one node going to other nodes that are obtained after the modification. Each edge also can have a probability associated with it. And the above random process is nothing but a random walk on this graph. So we know that this process is a Markov Chain(see the last reference at the end of the post ). We would want the Markov Chain to be ergodic and aperiodic(if the graph is undirected this just meens it should be connected and non bipartite) so that it converges to the stationary distribution. Also stationary distribution should be the distribution from which we want to sample. For this procedure to be efficient, the Markov Chain should converge to stationery distribution fast. This is done by proving that it is a rapidly mixing Markov Chain.

Reference

Shuffling cards and stopping times- ►duke.edu [PDF] D Aldous, P Diaconis - The American Mathematical Monthly, 1986 - jstor.org

Does Anything Happen at Random? : A talk by Persi Diaconis [youtube=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nAxEzxHkqyY] Rapidly Mixing Markov Chains [A write up my myself]

item.title: The Secretary Problem
item.dc:creator: girishvarma
item.content:encoded:
Suppose a secretary has to call $latex n$ candidates for a job interview. She can choose to call them in a random order. Assuming she does so, and the situation is take him or loose him(ie after having interviewed a person, she has to immediately tell him whether she will take him or not). An additional assumption is that all candidates will have distinct interview scores. So the question is "What is her best strategy?"(ie the one that maximizes the probability that she gets the candidate with the best score). One strategy is to interview half the people, find the best score and accept the next guy with a higher score. So if the best guy is in the second half and second best guy is in the first half which happens with probability $latex 1/4$, she will be able to get the best candidate. One could generalize the above and decide to find the best score among the first $latex k$ candidates and choose the next guy who beats this score. With some asymptotic analysis, the probability of finding the best guy comes to $latex \alpha\ln(1/ \alpha)$ where $latex \alpha = k/n$.(see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secretary_problem#Deriving_the_optimal_policy). This is maximized when $latex \alpha = 1/e$ giving a success probability of $latex 1/e$ . It can be proved that this is the best that can be achieved. The probabilists way of stating this is a sequence of random variables $latex X_1 \cdots X_n$ of scores. Since all candidates have different scores, $latex X_1 \cdots X_n$ is a random permutation of the scores(as we assumed that she calls candidates in a random order, and lets also assume that the scores are independent of what time they are taken). To make things slightly more complicated, let $latex Y_i$ be the indicator random variable for $latex X_i < \max(X_1\cdots X_{i-1})$.  After having seen $latex X_1 \cdots X_{i-1}$(these form $latex i-1$ distinct numbers with $latex i$ gaps between them),  $latex X_i$ is equally likely to be in anyone of  the gaps. Therefore

$latex \Pr[Y_i = 1] = \Pr[X_i < \max(X_1\cdots X_{i-1})] = \frac{1}{i}$

Claim : $latex Y_i$ is independent of $latex Y_1 \cdots Y_{i-1}$

Proof : Following the logic which gave the probability above, whether $latex X_i$ is the maximum of whats seen till now doesnt depend on the ordering of $latex X_1 \cdots X_{i-1}$. We want to know what the best stratergy is. Suppose we have already seen $latex X_1 \cdots X_n$, we have no option but to choose the $latex n$th candidate.

If $latex Y_n = 1$, with probability 1 we have the best guy, else its 0. For later purposes lets define $latex V(n,1)=1,V(n,0)=0$

Now again Whats the best strategy to follow once we have seen $latex X_1 \cdots X_{n-1}$.

If $latex Y_n = 1$,

  1. with probability $latex n-1/n$ we have the best guy
  2. if we skip this guy with probability $latex \Pr[Y_n=1|Y_{n-1}=1]\times 1 + \Pr[Y_n=0|Y_{n-1}=1]\times 0$ it will be found in the next step if the best strategy is followed from next step.
So we can compute these 2  values and choose the option with higher probability.  Let $latex V(n-1,1) = \max $ above 2 values

If $latex Y_n = 0$,

  1. with probability $latex 0$ we have the best guy
  2. if we skip this guy with probability $latex \Pr[Y_n=1|Y_{n-1}=1]\times 1 + \Pr[Y_n=1|Y_{n-1}=1]\times 0$ it will be found in the next step if the best strategy is followed from next step.
So the best thing is to skip. Let $latex V(n-1,1) = $ second value. And we can continue this inductively. Suppose $latex V(i+1,b)$ be the probability of success if the best strategy is  followed from step $latex i+1$ given $latex Y_{i+1}=b$. $latex V(i,b) = \max \{ i/n , \Pr[Y_{i+1}=1|Y_{i}=b]\times V(i+1,1) + \Pr[Y_n=0|Y_{n-1}=1]\times V(i+1,0) \}$ If $latex b=1$ then $latex V(i,1)= \max \{ i/n , \frac{1}{i+1}\times V(i+1,1) + \frac{i}{i+1}\times V(i+1,0) \} $ else $latex V(i,0)=i/n$  (ie if current is not the best among the candidates so far seen, he is definitely not best among all and so  we skip, hoping that best guy is yet to come). As $latex i/n$ is increasing in $latex i$, and it can be proved that $latex \frac{1}{i+1}\times V(i+1,1) + \frac{i}{i+1}\times V(i+1,0)$ is decreasing(i think after some threshold) at some point they cross. So from this point onwards we will choose the first guy that has best score so far(ie max is obtained for option 1). But we had already proved that best among such strategies is obtained by setting the threshold point to $latex 1/e$ to obtain a probability of getting best guy as $latex 1/e$.[this is slightly rough write up, i hope to improve it later]

item.title: Protests are On : Guess for What?
item.dc:creator: girishvarma
item.content:encoded:
TIFR research scholars are on protest mode, to be exact peaceful protest mode. The reason being the obvious one "we want a stipend hike". The latest pay commision reccomendations are being implemented and has increased the salaries across the board for faculties and staff in educational institutes. Research scholars not being considered as employees but rather students, have been ignored. The problem is atleast in TIFR, research scholars are supposed to be "highly talented and motivated"(to qoute the admission brochure) and some surely are. But how is TIFR going to attract these "highly talented and motivated" people if it doesn't provide competitive stipends? Unforunately the people who are supposed to decide on these matters lives in a office far away putting tick and cross marks on files. He doesn't understand the problem, for him the question is how to minimize the spending in this part so that spending in some other popular part is increased. The director understands the problem but is left comletely powerless in this matter. But he stil have to endure the frustration of the students. Even some faculty believes that in the cause. But if the frustration overflows the goodwill might be lost.
Being a beneficiary I offcourse support the protest. But instead of just demanding a stipend hike, a broader goal must be set. That is to remove the innefficency in the system. This would ensure more support to the cause(even from within the high ranks of the system) and will hopefully give a permanent solution. But some narrow minded people say why care about what happens after we leave the institute and all I want is my stipend to be hiked as soon as possible.

item.title: Undirected Reachability in Log Space
item.dc:creator: girishvarma
item.content:encoded:
Theorem[by Omer Reingold] : Given a undirected graph $latex {G([n],E)}&fg=000000$ and $latex {s,t\in [n]}&fg=000000$, the question ``Is there a path between $latex {s}&fg=000000$ and $latex {t}&fg=000000$?'' can be answered in space $latex {O(\log n)}&fg=000000$
All graphs mentioned in the proof are undirected and may have multiple edges. $latex {[n]}&fg=000000$ denotes $latex {\{1\cdots n\}}&fg=000000$. The problem is equivalent to outputting all vertices reachable from $latex {s}&fg=000000$ in $latex {O(\log n)}&fg=000000$ space, or more generally seperating the connected components in $latex {G}&fg=000000$. But one of the vertices may be reachable only by an $latex {O(n)}&fg=000000$ length path from $latex {s}&fg=000000$, and it might be a degree $latex {1}&fg=000000$ vertex. Since this $latex {O(n)=\ell}&fg=000000$ length path can be an arbitrary one, the only way i can think of is by brute force checking of all $latex {\ell}&fg=000000$ length paths. But the number of such paths can be exponential in $latex {n}&fg=000000$ !. If degree is $latex {d}&fg=000000$, it can be as large as $latex {d^\ell}&fg=000000$. However if the graph is such that all nodes reachable from $latex {s}&fg=000000$ are at a distance $latex {O(\log n)}&fg=000000$, then brute force is a viable method. Such a property is true in special graphs called expanders which are graphs whose adjacency matrix have small second eigen values. The proof basically constructs an expander from an arbitrary undirected graph preserving the reachability between vertices in $latex {O(\log n)}&fg=000000$ space. My aim is just to show the logic that leads to the proof. So i just state the main lemmas without proofs and some definitions. Proofs of the lemmas could be found in Emanuele Viola's Lecture notes. First step is to reduce the reachability question in $latex {G([n],E)}&fg=000000$ between vertices to reachability question between large connected subsets $latex {S,T \subset [n^{'}], |S|,|T| \geq \frac{|n^{'}|}{3}}&fg=000000$ in some $latex {G^{'}([n^{'}],E^{'})}&fg=000000$ which is $latex {4}&fg=000000$-regular graph and has a self loop on every node.
Reduction 1:There is an algorithm which on input $latex {G([n],E)}&fg=000000$ and $latex {s,t \in [n]}&fg=000000$, that uses only $latex {O(\log n)}&fg=000000$ spaces and outputs
  • a $latex {4}&fg=000000$-regular graph with a self-loop on all verices $latex {G^{'}([n^{'}],E^{'})}&fg=000000$
  • $latex {S^{'},T^{'} \subset [n^{'}]}&fg=000000$, such that $latex {|S^{'}|,|T^{'}|\geq n^{'}/3}&fg=000000$
  • the induced subgraphs of $latex {G^{'}}&fg=000000$ on $latex {S^{'}}&fg=000000$ and $latex {T^{'}}&fg=000000$ are connected
such that

there is a path between $latex {s,t}&fg=000000$ in $latex {G}&fg=000000$ $latex {\Leftrightarrow}&fg=000000$ there is path between $latex {S^{'}}&fg=000000$ to $latex {T^{'}}&fg=000000$.

But this is actually not a simpler problem. The trouble I mentioned about $latex {G}&fg=000000$ still remains valid here. But this makes the problem simple for spectral analysis. Note that if you have a graph without self loops and then add self loops to all nodes, $latex {k}&fg=000000$ length paths in the latter corresponds to $latex {\leq k}&fg=000000$ length paths in the former(this is a many-one, surjective map). Another reason for doing this is to make the graph non-bipartite, which is required for the application of the next result. Its a well known fact that the second eigen value of the adjacency matrix is related to how connected a graph is. Lower the eigen value, the graph is better connected. Following is how the second eigen value is defined.
Definition 1 :

$latex \displaystyle \lambda(G) := \max_{||x||=1,x \perp \mathbf{1}} ||Mx||&fg=000000$

where $latex {M=A/D}&fg=000000$ the normailized adjacency matrix of $latex {G}&fg=000000$, and $latex {\mathbf{1}}&fg=000000$ is the all 1's vector.
For a complete graph $latex {\lambda = 0}&fg=000000$ and $latex {\lambda = 1}&fg=000000$ if and only if the graph is disconnected or it is bipartite. For a connected undirected graph $latex {\lambda(G)\leq 1 - \frac{1}{n^c}}&fg=000000$.
Lemma 1 : For any connected, non-bipartite undirected graph $latex {G}&fg=000000$ on $latex {n}&fg=000000$ vertices

$latex \displaystyle \lambda(G) \leq 1- \frac{1}{n^c}&fg=000000$

for some constant $latex {c}&fg=000000$.
It is known that if $latex {\lambda(G)}&fg=000000$ is small, the number of edges between subsets of the vertex set is proportional to the product sizes of the subsets with a small additive term. This is known as the Expander mixing lemma. The following is a corollary of this lemma
Lemma 2 : For a $latex {D}&fg=000000$-regular graph $latex {G([m],E)}&fg=000000$ and $latex {S,T \subset [m],\ |S|,|T| \geq m/3}&fg=000000$, if $latex {\lambda(G) \leq 1/10}&fg=000000$ then there is an edge between $latex {S}&fg=000000$ and $latex {T}&fg=000000$.
So Lemma 2 says that, if $latex {\lambda(G^{'})}&fg=000000$ is small, then we just need to check whether there is a direct edge to $latex {T}&fg=000000$. This can be done provided the degree of nodes in $latex {S}&fg=000000$ are not high ie exponential in $latex {n}&fg=000000$(can happen if there are multiple edges). The naive method to do here is to make a graph in which edges consists of length $latex {2}&fg=000000$ paths in orginal graph, called $latex {G^2}&fg=000000$. Its easy to prove that this will make the second eigen value $latex {\lambda^2}&fg=000000$. Doing this $latex {O(\log n)}&fg=000000$ times will make $latex {\lambda \leq 1/10}&fg=000000$ but the degree becomes $latex {D^{2^{O(\log n)}} = D^{O(n)}}&fg=000000$. The above method actually corresponds to making a graph whose edges represent long paths in orginal graph as mentioned in the begining. Next is a method for reducing $latex {\lambda(G)}&fg=000000$ without blowing up the degree. This corresponds to considering only a small subset of the exponential number of paths possible and it will be proved that this is good enough.
Definition 2 :
  • $latex {G}&fg=000000$ is said to be an $latex {(m,D,\lambda)}&fg=000000$-graph iff its vertex set is $latex {[m]}&fg=000000$, it is $latex {D}&fg=000000$-regular, and has $latex {\lambda(G) \leq \lambda}&fg=000000$.
  • If $latex {X}&fg=000000$ is an $latex {(m,D,\lambda)}&fg=000000$-graph and $latex {G}&fg=000000$ is an $latex {(D,d,\mu)}&fg=000000$-graph then $latex {X\circledS G}&fg=000000$ is a $latex {(m,Dd,\lambda^{'})}&fg=000000$-graph. For $latex {v \in [m]}&fg=000000$ the $latex {(a,b)}&fg=000000$th neighbour of $latex {v}&fg=000000$ denoted by $latex {v[(a,b)]}&fg=000000$ is $latex {(v[a])[a[b]]}&fg=000000$ where $latex {v[a]}&fg=000000$ is the $latex {a}&fg=000000$th neigbour of $latex {v}&fg=000000$ in $latex {X}&fg=000000$, and $latex {a[b]}&fg=000000$ is the $latex {b}&fg=000000$th neighbour of $latex {a}&fg=000000$ in $latex {G}&fg=000000$ (according to the induced ordering on the neighbours due to the ordering on the vertex set).
The $latex {\circledS}&fg=000000$ operation is similar to graph squaring but the number of neighbours becomes $latex {dD}&fg=000000$ instead of $latex {D^2}&fg=000000$ in $latex {G^2}&fg=000000$. This is especially good if the $latex {D >> d}&fg=000000$. The next lemma states that the $latex {\circledS}&fg=000000$ operation also decreases the eigen value.

Lemma 3 :

$latex \displaystyle \lambda(X \circledS G) \leq (1-\mu)\lambda^2+\mu&fg=000000$

Instead of considering all $latex {D^2}&fg=000000$ vertices at distance $latex {2}&fg=000000$, we are considering only some $latex {Dd}&fg=000000$ neigbours. Now we will apply the $latex {\circledS}&fg=000000$ operation $latex {O(\log n)}&fg=000000$ times to bring down $latex {\lambda(G)}&fg=000000$ to $latex {\leq 1/10}&fg=000000$ and the degree increases to $latex {Dd^{O(\log n)}}&fg=000000$. But after each $latex {\circledS}&fg=000000$ operation, the degree increases, and so we need a larger $latex {G}&fg=000000$ for doing the next $latex {\circledS}&fg=000000$ operation. Next lemma say there exists a sequence of $latex {G}&fg=000000$'s with small $latex {\mu}&fg=000000$'s.
Lemma 4 : There exists a sequence of $latex {(d^i,d,\mu)}&fg=000000$-graphs $latex {\{ G_i \}_{i\in \mathbb{N}}}&fg=000000$ where $latex {\mu \leq \frac{1}{100}}&fg=000000$.
Corollary If $latex {\lambda = 1 - \gamma \geq 1/10}&fg=000000$ and $latex {\mu \leq 1/100}&fg=000000$ then $latex {\lambda(X\circledS G) \leq 1 - \frac{12}{11}\gamma}&fg=000000$. So after $latex {t}&fg=000000$ $latex {\circledS}&fg=000000$ operations, $latex \displaystyle \lambda(X\circledS^t \{G_i\}_{i=1}^t) = \lambda(((X\circledS G_1)\cdots )\circledS G_t) \leq 1 - \left(\frac{12}{11}\right)^t\gamma&fg=000000$ If $latex {\gamma \geq 1/n^c}&fg=000000$, for $latex {t=O(\log n)}&fg=000000$, $latex \displaystyle \lambda(X\circledS^t \{G_i\}_{i=1}^t) \leq \frac{1}{10}&fg=000000$
In the above corollary what is effectively done is that we have constructed a graph $latex {G^{''}=X\circledS^t \{G_i\}_{i=1}^t}&fg=000000$ , in which edges represent $latex {poly(n)}&fg=000000$ long walks in $latex {G^{'}}&fg=000000$. Clearly if all $latex {poly(n)}&fg=000000$ length paths were considered($latex {4^{poly(n)}}&fg=000000$) as edges(this corresponds to squaring the graph many times), one cannot even find all the neighbours of a node in log space. So we consider only a carefully choosen sparse subset($latex {poly(n)}&fg=000000$) by means of the $latex {\circledS}&fg=000000$ operation. Here is an example of the above procedure done on the board(my mobile has a bad camera, but the image should be viewable at the full size) Now for this to be done by a log space machine, the $latex {(a_1,a_2,\cdots a_t)}&fg=000000$th neighbour ($latex {a_1 \in [D]}&fg=000000$, and all other $latex {a_i \in [d]}&fg=000000$)of any vertex in $latex {G^{''}=X\circledS^t \{G_i\}_{i=1}}&fg=000000$ should be computable in log space. Each $latex {(a_1,a_2,\cdots a_t)}&fg=000000$th neighbour is obtained by doing a walk of length $latex 2^{poly(n)}$ on $latex X_0$. This walk is specified by a sequence of choices of neighbours $latex b_1,b_2,\cdots b_{2^{poly(n)}}&fg=000000$. The following figure illustrates how to compute $latex b_i$ given $latex {(a_1,a_2,\cdots a_t)}&fg=000000$ and $latex i$. The $latex {(a_1,a_2,\cdots a_t)}&fg=000000$ neighbour ($latex {a_1 \in [D]}&fg=000000$, and all other $latex {a_i \in [d]}&fg=000000$)of any vertex in $latex G^{''}=X\circledS^t \{G_i\}_{i=1}^{t}&fg=000000$ is computable in space $latex {O(\log n)}&fg=000000$, for $latex {t=O(\log n)}&fg=000000$.
Lemma 5 : Reachability question in $latex {G^{'}(V^{'},E^{'})}&fg=000000$($latex {4}&fg=000000$ regular) between large connected subsets $latex {S,T \subset V^{'}, |S|,|T| \geq \frac{|V^{'}|}{3}}&fg=000000$ can be reduced in log space to the question whether there is an edge between large subsets $latex {S^{''},T^{''}, |S^{''}|,|T^{''}| \geq \frac{|V^{''}|}{3}}&fg=000000$ in some graph $latex {G^{''}(V^{''},E^{''})}&fg=000000$ in which neigbours of any vertex can be computed in log space.

item.title: Streaming Algorithms Workshop at IITK
item.dc:creator: girishvarma
item.content:encoded: There was a workshop on streaming algos right after FSTTCS at IIT Kanpur. First of all iitk has an awesome campus really spacious with lots of sports facilities. Though I didn't understand most of the talks, I got a vague idea of the problems and how they are solved. Streaming algos are heavily used in applications like web search, databases, routers etc. These algos work on a looong stream of data(say of length $latex n$), over which they can do only a few passes($latex 1$, a const, or $latex o(\log n)$), keeping only small memory($latex O(1)$ or $latex O(\log n)$). Though they have been around for some time, the big push in the area came after the ams paper(all the speakers referenced this paper and for this the authors won the godel prize). This paper gave approximate randomized one pass algorithm for frequency moments using small space. One another important feature is that they also proved lowerbounds using communication complexity. This was an awesome idea and has been successfully used to obtain lower bounds for other streaming problems. Some of the problems were based on the specifiations that these applications require and some purely theoretical. The first problem is to define a good model of computation that abstracts actual appliccations. Since the applications are different you need to look at different models. People talked about models of distributed streaming computations, models in which on can annotate the stream or write to it, copies of streams can be maintained, multiple passes allowed(the ams paper just looked at simple one pass read only stream). Many streaming algos work by making a small sketch of the streaming data in there small memory. Later it extracts the requred information about the stream from the sketch. Usually hash functions are used to make sketches. People seems to have mastered the art of using communication complexity to prove lowerbounds. Even for multiple passes they consider the communication complexity for multiple rounds of communication. There was some talk on 2 other methods called information complexity and round elemibation.

item.title: Flow problems on graphs
item.dc:creator: girishvarma
item.content:encoded:
Let $latex G(V,E)$ be a directed graph. Given $latex s,t \in V$, $latex f:V \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is said to be a flow from $latex s$ to $latex t$ if flow is conserved at every vertex except $latex s,t$($latex \forall v \in V \setminus \{s,t\},~ \sum_{u | (u,v) \in E} f(u,v) = \sum_{u | (v,u) \in E} f(v,u)$) and $latex f$ is skew symmetric($latex f(u,v) = - f(v,u)$). $latex f:V \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is said to be a circulation in $latex G$, if the flow is conserved at all vertices. The following problems are well studied in literature:

MAX-FLOW

Given some capacities for the edges $latex G,~ c:E \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^+$ and $latex s,t \in V$, find a flow $latex f$ from $latex s$ to $latex t$ that satisfies the constraints $latex \forall e \in E,~ f(e) \leq c(e)$ and maximizes the value ($latex \sum_{u| (s,u) \in E} f(s,u) - \sum_{u| (u,s) \in E} f(u,s)$).

MIN-FLOW

Given $latex r \in \mathbb{R}^+$, costs for the edges $latex G,~ c:E \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^+$ and $latex s,t \in V$, find a flow $latex f$ from $latex s$ to $latex t$ that has value $latex r$ ($latex \sum_{u| (s,u) \in E} f(s,u) - \sum_{u| (u,s) \in E} f(u,s) = r$) and minimizes the total cost ($latex \sum_{e \in E} f(e) c(e)$).

MIN-CIRCULATION

Given costs for the edges $latex G,~ c:E \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^+$, find a circulation $latex f$ that minimizes the total cost ($latex \sum_{e \in E} f(e) c(e)$).

MAX-MULTICOMMODITY-FLOW

Given commodities $latex K_1,\cdots K_t$, where $latex K_i$ is the tuple $latex (s_i,t_i,d_i)$(ie source, destination and demand), and capacities for the edges $latex G,~ c:E \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^+$, find flows $latex f_i, \forall \in [t]$ from $latex s_i$ to $latex t_i$ that satisfies the capacity constraints ($latex \forall e \in E,~ \sum_{i \in [t]} f_i(e) \leq c(e)$) and maximizes the value ($latex \sum_{i \in [t]} \sum_{u| (s_i,u) \in E} f_i(s_i,u) - \sum_{u| (u,s_i) \in E} f(u,s_i)$).

MIN-MULTICOMMODITY-FLOW

Given commodities $latex K_1,\cdots K_t$, where $latex K_i$ is the tuple $latex (s_i,t_i,d_i)$(ie source, destination and demand), and costs for the edges $latex c:E \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^+$, find flows $latex f_i, \forall \in [t]$ from $latex s_i$ to $latex t_i$ that satisfies the demand($latex \forall i \in [t],\sum_{u \mid (s_i ,u) \in E} f_i(s_i,u) - \sum_{u \mid (u,s_i) \in E} f(u,s_i) = d_i$) and minimizes the costs ($latex \sum_{e \in E} \sum_{i \in [t]} f_i(e) c(e)$). All these problems can be solved with linear programming, by having a variable for every vertex and putting the constraints, optimization as linear functions on them. But the problem is when one requires a solution for the variables that takes integer values(integral solution), these becomes hard. There is one exception of MAX-FLOW, because of the MAX-FLOW MIN-CUT theorem, if the capacities are integral, the maximum flow has integral value. Finding an integral solution for the MIN-MULTICOMMODITY-FLOW is NP-HARD, even if there are only two commodities. The MIN-MULTICOMMODITY-FLOW is used to model congestion and routing in the internet. The costs on the edges are just the latencies(the amount of time required for a unit of data to be transfered between the ends of a link). One would like to find how the packets from $latex s_i$s to $latex t_i$s need to be routed so as to minimize the total latency. But in actual networks the latency of a link increases when more flow is routed through it due to queuing in the devices. So we need the latency on the edges to be increasing functions of the flow rather than just scalars. Also in the internet routing of packets are not controlled by a central authority. So what is assumed is each packet takes a route so as to minimize its latency. Such a flow is called the Nash flow. But such a process need not minimize the total latency incurred by all the packets. The ratio between the largest latency of Nash flows by the Optimal total latency is called the Price of Anarchy.
